messages: fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (20:45): hey, i have a solaris workstation here at work and i forgot the root password.  any ideas on how i can extract it?
fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (20:46): someone in another room suggested using a bootcd, chrooting, and typing passwd root
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (20:46): chibi_killstick, boot off cd mount your root partition
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (20:46): modify your /etc/shadow
daa08b04a71644cbce3e6e7e5aeeb58e (20:46): reboot
8a2ec3d80a45ba71f61da6da97613e11 (20:53): so sad...rather than figuring out how to change this pig over from dhcp to a static IP setup, I'm making the IT guy setup a dhcp reservation...
fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (21:00): rodrickbrown: how do i modify /etc/shadow?
fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (21:01): rodrickbrown: as in what should i change it to?
13d302032f9ecb786adfb94061757afc (21:03): I think setting it to nothing should make the user have no password. or you could paste a known crypt block.
fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (21:04): Cyrille: excellent.  i tried using a Gentoo boot cd just now, but it didn't seem to accept it
8a2ec3d80a45ba71f61da6da97613e11 (21:05): chibi_killstick: http://www.horizondatacom.com/services/articles/articleindex/article00006.php
8a2ec3d80a45ba71f61da6da97613e11 (21:05): that's for if it is an actual sun machine (complete with sun keyboard)
fcf2f52f2ffcaa3d317f3664fdf54276 (21:06): Abnix: which it is...
8a2ec3d80a45ba71f61da6da97613e11 (21:06): ahh, good good

da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:29): guys, i have a wierd problem with cron.. i can execute the script manually, (all env variables are in script) but cron just wont run it ?
0ef8ee0341311e56b8a0008754347fdf (22:30): do you get any errors ?
0ef8ee0341311e56b8a0008754347fdf (22:31): normally cron emails error output to the cron owner (root or whatever user)
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:31): is it executable by the user who's crontab it's in?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:31): cron emails you any output
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:31): unless you redirect standard output to /dev/null
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:31): and unless you redirect error output to /dev/null
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:31): yes, script is executable by oracle user, no error no emails ?
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:31): email are going to a log file i believe
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:31): Snake007uk: not unless you're doing > /dev/null 2>&1
0ef8ee0341311e56b8a0008754347fdf (22:32): where does email to "oracle" go ?
819b92989620e5de10a57e7b8251049d (22:32): Snake007uk, post the line from cron
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:32): delewis: but even if you redirect, cron will still email if it *can't run* your command.
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:32): delewis:  one sec i think i may have the answer :)
819b92989620e5de10a57e7b8251049d (22:32): also, is it in oracle's cron, or roots?
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:33): Snake007uk: su -l oracle -c 'crontab -l' shows what?
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (22:33): g4lt-U60: 900$ would be okay i think (in europe it would)
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:34): now that I know it's FC-AL, yeah, $900 is about right
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:34): especially since disks are dirt cheap and the 280 has the typical enterprise internal diskrack from hell
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:35): no, 36's, but FC is cheap
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (22:35): charlieS: fire 280r
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:35): FC is cheap? eh.. what?
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:36): charlieS, epay for fc disks, there's no secondhand market for them at all
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:36): you should be able to get a 300G FC drive for $1000 though. (google, not Sun)
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:36): yes there is g4lt-U60 :)
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:36): they're worse than SCA for secondhand
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (22:36): yeah
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:36): it must have grown up in the last month or so then
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (22:36): not many systems use them, only sgi/sun
94ece629302b8d297aacee2baaf20ac0 (22:36): mostly
8c27c6238210e78d0cff9690db08116b (22:38): name 160 sun hobbyists ;P
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:38): if you google by model number you can normally find people selling them.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:38): 1Gb/s FC drives are pretty cheap.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:39): chaper than U320, but a bit more expensive than U160
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (22:39): likewise 1Gb/s performance is somewhere in between U320 and U160, realistically.
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): ok cron doesnt seem to want to run for oracle user
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): 35 18 * * *     /opt/oracle/local/sql/hot_backup.sh >> /tmp/backups/oracle/backup-logs/backup-log.txt 2>&1
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): is the original entry
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): and then i tired
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): 38 18 * * * /opt/oracle/test.sh
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): and it wont run that script ?
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:43): the script just does "ls -l >/tmp/testing
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:44): check /etc/cron.d/cron.allow
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:44): (and man crontab explains it)
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:44): er, and cron.deny
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:45): there is no cron.allow
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:45): or deny
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:45): that's why. read the crontab manpage.
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:45): ok
da0e57e706a98c1977faf3a3cf26b5eb (22:51): charlieS: i created cron.deny but oracle still cant execute ?
5ca559c44d113ea4b7115a4a5563006f (22:53): Snake007uk: weird.. where does mail to oracle go?
